chunks.text: In Ohio, hospitals handling controlled substances must maintain a Terminal Distributor of Dangerous Drugs (TDDD) certificate. Schedule II controlled substances require an active TDDD registration and documented certificate number.

Ohio requires a TDDD certificate number for hospital facilities distributing or storing controlled substances. Facilities must keep the certificate current and provide the TDDD certificate identifier on request.
Practitioners prescribing or handling Schedule II controlled substances must hold a valid DEA registration. DEA registration is required before dispensing controlled substances in any jurisdiction.
When a license expiration date is missing or expired, compliance review is required before approval. Review must confirm current licensure and supporting documentation.
New York pharmacies must hold an active state license and comply with controlled substance handling requirements. Missing license documentation requires manual verification.
